description: Data was loaded from the Ensembl gene-set, Release 87, dated December 2016. This Homo sapiens, GRCh38 data was downloaded using the Ensemble GTF (ftp://ftp.ensembl.org/pub/release-87/gtf/homo_sapiens/Homo_sapiens.GRCh38.87.gtf.gz). More details: see README at ftp://ftp.ensembl.org/pub/release-87/gtf/homo_sapiens/README. The Ensembl license is at http://uswest.ensembl.org/info/about/legal/code_licence.html

fields.description: E.g., havana, ensembl_havana, ensembl, mirbase, or insdc
fields.name: source

fields.description: E.g., an exon, CDS, five_prime_UTR, transcript, etc.
fields.name: feature

fields.description: + or -, for forward or reverse strand. DNA is double-stranded. By convention, for a reference chromosome, one whole strand is designated the forward strand and the other the reverse strand. This designation is arbitrary. Sometimes the terms plus strand and minus strand are used instead.
fields.name: strand

fields.description: Gene name, e.g., TTN, DDR1, etc. See https://m.ensembl.org/info/genome/genebuild/gene_names.html
fields.name: gene_name

fields.description: Ensembl gene ID. Stable IDs are created in the form ENS[species prefix][feature type prefix][a unique eleven digit number]. For example, a mouse gene might be ENSMUSG###########. For human, there is no species code, so IDs are in the form ENS(object type)(identifier).(version). E.g., ENSG00000183091. See https://useast.ensembl.org/Help/Faq?id=488
fields.name: gene_id

fields.description: Possible sources: either ensembl_havana, havana, ensembl, or insdc
fields.name: gene_source

fields.description: Ensembl transcript ID. Stable IDs are created in the form ENS[species prefix][feature type prefix][a unique eleven digit number].For human, there is no species code, so IDs are in the form ENS(object type)(identifier).(version)E.g, ENT00000589042.
fields.name: transcript_id

fields.description: Possible sources: either ensembl_havana, havana, ensembl, or insdc
fields.name: transcript_source

fields.description: Position number in set of of exons for parent gene. See https://useast.ensembl.org/info/genome/genebuild/genome_annotation.html
fields.name: exon_number

fields.description: Ensembl exon ID. Stable IDs are created in the form ENS[species prefix][feature type prefix][a unique eleven digit number].For human, there is no species code, so IDs are in the form ENS(object type)(identifier).(version).E.g, ENSE00003674202
fields.name: exon_id

fields.description: E.g., CCDS54424 (or blank)The CCDS project is a collaborative effort to identify a core set ofprotein coding regions that are consistently annotated and of high quality. The CCDS set is built by consensus among Ensembl, the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), and the HUGO Gene Nomenclature Committee (HGNC) for human or Mouse Genome Informatics (MGI) for mouse. Annotated genes that are included in the CCDS set are associated with a unique identifier number and version number (e.g., CCDS1.1, CCDS234.1). The version number will update if the CDS structure changes, or if the underlying genome sequence changes at that location. See https://useast.ensembl.org/info/genome/genebuild/ccds.html
fields.name: ccds_id

fields.description: E. g., ENSP00000467141 or blank. The primary ID for the proteins defined in Ensembl and each (protein coding) Ensembl transcript has one protein ID assigned to it. See https://useast.ensembl.org/Help/Faq?id=488
fields.name: protein_id

fields.description: Semi-colon delimited list of tags. E.g.,CCDS;basic
fields.name: tag
